Volume is a stealth game where the main objective is to sneak your way through the levels, navigating around guards using different means such as whistling, hiding, throwing a distraction grenade type thing etc. Ultimately, the goal of the entire level is to collect all of the cones and reach the exit. There are 100 levels of the main story which will take you around 10hrs to complete. Every few levels a new element is added to the game which will change the way you play out the next few levels while some narrative/story telling goes on.

Firstly, I want to talk about positives. The games option menu is good. It's perfect and what you should expect from a game like this. Different sliders for volume, AA, shadow settings, resolution and fs/windowed. All keys are remappable (for keyboard). I also really like the art style. It's really unique, colourful and visually appealing.

Unfortunately, there are a lot of negatives for me. (Please remember this is my personal opinion so please keep that in mind and be respectful).
Ok first the voice acting. The voice acting of the robot (Alan) is well done. I believe it's the same voice that narrated TWA. But then your characters voice (Locksley/Rob) is a bit meh to be honest. As soon as he says a few lines it completely breaks the immersion of the game for me.

Secondly, I would like to talk about the AI. The AI seem to suffer from a very serious case of short sightedness. Their entire view is about 2m in length and spews out in a cone shape. This means you can literally stand 2.1m in length away from them and bingo! They can't even see you! Or you can stand right by the side of them (clearly being in their peripheral vision) but they won't know any different! reviewText:
Volume is Metal Gear Solid burned down to it's very core, keeping it simple with classic stealth game tropes but not losing the fun in the process. I have been looking forward to playing Volume for a long time, as I am a big fan of it's creator Mike Bithell, who also created Thomas Was Alone.

Instead of taking place in large areas with different rooms, Volume is set in multiple small levels. Each one has a different colour scheme and layout, so you don't have to worry about getting bored quickly. The game has a very minimalistic (cheap, hehe) design, similar to Thomas Was Alone, but in a 3D enviroment. All in all, Volume is a beautiful game. However, I must note that a lack of a death animation or even sound effect means that death has almost zero impact. The fact that all items aren't already loaded when you pick them up or respawn means that you sometimes also have to wait around for them to hurry up so you can use them.

It is also oozing with charm, with spot-on voice acting featuring not only multiple YouTubers such as Charlie McDonnell, Jim Sterling and Dan Bull, but also Andy Serkis, from Lord of the Rings and Planet of the Apes fame. The dialogue is brilliantly written, with humour often tucked in. There is also plenty of backstory to read while wondering through the levels, which adds a nice layer of mystery to the game's plot.

For the speedrunners out there, leaderboards for the time it takes to complete a level are placed to add a layer of challenge to the already rather difficult game. I wouldn't advise rushing through it though: take your time to marvel at the visuals, laugh at the dialogue and read through the creative backstorys.

Everything about Volume reeks of Mike Bithell, from the design to the wonderful music, composed by Thomas Was Alone composer David Housden. If you liked Thomas Was Alone or the Metal Gear Solid series, you will adore Volume.

Volume is not what I thought it would be but is still a well-made game. I had envisioned some sort of top-down Mark of the Ninja type stealth game. Instead, Volume presents a progressively harder series of challenge maps. I've played for an hour and all the ones I've seen are quite small, as in they can be beaten on your first run through in anywhere from 10 to 90 seconds. There is a story but it's kind of meh and involves a lot of side reading.

My main disappointment is the focus isn't so much on finishing the levels as it is doing it as quickly as possible to try and compete on the leaderboards. If you're like me and don't care so much about leaderboards, you will blow through a lot of levels and they won't leave much of an impression on you. So far each level I played was pretty easy as long as I took my time. The only difficulty stems from trying to rush through a map.

However, I like the graphics, the spoken dialogue, the music, the virtual atmosphere, and the gameplay & controls were designed well (if you're using a gamepad, at least; haven't tried with keyboard controls). They also have a level editor and allow people to post online challege maps. And if you DO like leaderboards and speed runs, this will be a real treat for you.

TL;DR
Good game, just not my cup of tea.

reviewText:
So, I just finished this lovely game.

It goes by the name of Volume.

Back when I first heard about it, I knew I had to have it.

It's essentially a cyberpunk re-imagining of Robin Hood mixed with VR Missions from Metal Gear Solid.
If that's not enough to make you rush and pick it up I don't know what else to say.

But let me start at the beginning, that's where all the good stories start I hear. If you're lazy and want to know if it's good that's down at the bottom, somewhere. (Yes, it's good.) (it's  at the bottom too)

In this game you start simply enough with a few things you can do such as crouch against walls and walk around and explore. Then there is information that is gathered which sheds some light on the world, and provides a nice way to introduce backstory without a ton of exposition that people will hit escape on. The world is there, the world is substantial. I was invested in this world, not because I've lived it, but due to the excellent writing and narrative it provided.

The writing was humourous, light-hearted and entertaining where it was needed and serious enough to drive this story of corruption and power.

After the first few missions you start obtaining items that can be picked up and used, but only one at a time so plan accordingly. These vary through each map, so you're never feeling completely comfortable or stuck with an  item.

When I sat down with this game, I told myself that I would play it for a couple hours and then I would do a work in progress review. Four hours later I hit the halfway mark, and I kept going. Seventy-five percent I said, and I'll do my review. Which brings us to now, Eight hours after I first clicked play. The game is complete, for now.

I am sad, only because I can't experience this again for the first time. But at the same time, I'm so excited, because now I have to look forward to the community levels making my own, going back through and beating my own time as well as fighting for a place on the leaderboards.

The soundtrack was hauntingly well done, filling every crevice in the game with a sense of wonder, and dread that that one frickin AI was going to just turn around and spot me and put an end to my shenanigans. Said shenanigans include throwing whistles through the air, turning invisible, dodging electric traps and lasers. It's like I'm a young James Bond, if only his bestie was a robot AI that kind of enjoyed sarcasm.

When I first set out in the game I had issues with it. I didn't like the voice actor for the main character, he sounded bored. But, as the game went on he grew on me. He wasn't bored, he was just alive, reacting normally how someone might react. There was no need for overhyped dialogue. It fit perfectly.

Sometimes the AI seemed a bit random in it's movements. Where one time I would do something and it would work and then die/get caught before the next checkpoint and do the exact same thing and it would fail. But, with patience I was able to get through those parts by finding a new creative way to push on through.

Sometimes the controls don't respond normally, and sometimes when you're in stealth or cover the AI enemies will bump into you and push you out and you get spotted.

Two of the bigger complaints I have is that sometimes the color choices for the level make it very hard to see where the AI is looking when patrolling, but that was rare, and that the enemies can walk through each other, but they're a brick wall to you.

Do those things take away from the game? Not one damn bit.
This will be sitting on my shelf" of games that I talk about for a long time. Up there with The Metal Gear Solid series and Gunpoint.

If it's not obvious and you find yourself asking "should I buy this game?"

The answer is a resounding 'Yes'

reviewText:
Volume is a pure stealth game with simplistic, yet beautiful colors encapsulating the English spirit.

The premise is simple: you are in a virtually generated room filled with guards and objects to collect, the goal simpler: get to the exit. Most of the times you are given a tool such as a distraction device or full out invisibility to help you along the way. There are 100 such rooms or levels that the developer included although the included level editor and community browser with weekly level staff picks provide a relatively healthy supply of fresh and exciting new rooms. It's fun but It feels very shallow in its entirety. The biggest flaw in the title is the linear design of the levels. Because you are given carefully picked tools to aid you in each level, the gameplay starts feeling like a puzzle solver. This inevitably severely limits your choices on how you would like to approach certain situations therefor making the levels lack in depth. Luckily it is innovative and unique enough to keep one interested.

Length wise It took me a little over seven hours to beat it in its entirety (100% achievements) but again, if you get hooked, user levels are always available. It's one of those games that I feel everyone would enjoy but its questionable how much you could take before you would feel bored. It's a bit of a hard recommendation looking at its steep price point but an excellent approach to visual level design, innovative gameplay and unique writing thematic makes me think its justified. If you like what you see, I've no doubt you will love it.

reviewText:
A game purely about stealth. It's elegant and simple design is this game's strong point but people looking for a more in depth experience may find the game lacking.

Volume's simplistic approach in both it's striking viuals and it's gameplay are what make the experience so worthwhile. The brilliant level design of the core 100 levels accentuate the solid gameplay and drip feed new abilities and mechanics as the game goes on, rarely leaving the player without some new concept to wrap their head around, although interest can wane over longer play sessions: I'd suggest take your time to enjoy the game in multiple play sessions.

Further more, Volume has a built in community level editor. You can create and share your own levels with the world, effectively giving the game endless replayability.

The cherry on the cake is an interesting Robin Hood story in a future dystopian England, even if it is prehaps not center piece to the experience.

For these reasons, the closest comparison to another game I'd have is to Little Big Planet: simple, charming, effective and (post end-game), community driven.

reviewText:
-At the time of writing this review, ive completed 75% of the game-

Volume is Mike Bithell's second game (the first one being 'Thomas was alone'), and it is incredibly good.

Storywise, the game is a futuristic retelling of the Robin Hood legend, in which Robin 'Rob' Locksley is not stealing from the rich and giving to the poor, but is instead streaming a simulation on how to do just that, without using violence. The people of England can then copy his moves and take back what they deserve by themselves.

Gameplay wise, it is a stealth game. Well to be precise, its a semi-minimalistic isometric hardcore non-lethal stealth game. The gameplay includes sneaking around (obviously), along with using all kinds of gadgets to distract guards and get from point A to B. Because Locksley does not intend to kill/maim guards, he did not bring any weapons. He cannot fight. if this is a problem for you, you will not enjoy this game. The objective is to collect all the gems (which represent valuables) in a level, and then continue to the exit. There are also walls that can be jumped over, closets/floorboards that can be hidden in/under, taps & toilets that can be activated, etc.

I really enjoyed each level, but they can feel slightly repetitive. Take breaks in between whille playing this. Playing it in one sitting is not advised.

The guards' AI is not perfect, and as a result, it is fairly easy to make them lose sight of you (provided there are lots of corners in your immediate vacinity). There are also a few minor bugs that still need to be ironed out (nothing gamebreaking though).

The voice acting and music are very well done. The music fits well with the game, and is frankly quite beautiful. The voice of the main antagonist (voiced by Andy Serkis) sounds really good too.


All in all, i personally really enjoy Volume, and i think Mike Bithell has definitely proven that he is not a 'one hit wonder'. The game is not perfect, but if you are a fan of hardcore stealth games, you will definitely enjoy this!

(I don't particularly enjoy giving games a score, but if i had to, it would be an 8/10)

reviewText:
You have to come in to Volume with the correct expectations to appreciate it. This isn’t a tightly told story like Thomas Was Alone. It’s more of a stealth arcade game, in the vein of the Metal Gear Solid VR missions.

Compared to Metal Gear Solid, Volume is simplified. You can’t crawl or hide in narrow spaces, there are no melee attacks, and your inventory is reset between levels. In any situation there’s usually only one way to progress, in a way that feels rigid. Because of your limited abilities, the challenges never feel particularly interesting. The solutions are immediately obvious, and it’s just a matter of brute force trial and error to get past. AI and checkpoints are easily exploitable in a way that feels like a deliberate design choice, as a workaround for you not having anything to do if you’re discovered. All this leads to levels feeling disposable. Once you’ve finished them once, there’s not much more you can do with them. It’s only slightly more complex than Thomas Was Alone in that sense. Compared to something like Thief, it’s more Trackmania than Gran Turismo. Every level is a one-off, instead of something you’ll be coming back to over and over to explore alternative solutions. I came in expecting this, so I was fine with it. But if you’re a hardcore stealth fan it might not be enough. Like Trackmania, Volume has a level editor, and there are already tons of new maps out there. I haven’t looked at them, but it wouldn’t surprise me if the game comes alive through them in a way that the campaign mode doesn’t.

The story was the greatest disappointment for me, mostly because of how underwritten it feels. There’s 100 levels in the campaign, and you go several levels at a time without seeing the ghost of the story. Levels are purportedly based on machines you’re hacking, where the dirty laundry of corrupt government officials and heads of corporations are shown to the world. But during levels this isn’t evident at all. I was hoping for something like Tron 2.0, where the visual design of the levels reflected the kinds of systems you were inside, with emails exposing the internal workings of the system. But Volume isn’t like that. This isn’t a grand story arc that unfolds over the 100 levels. Instead it’s a story for a game 1/5 this size, with the majority of the levels being there because it’d be poor value for money if it was any smaller. You do read emails and documents, but they seem to have no connection whatsoever to what’s going on. This is a complete waste, because this story needed more. It has loads of characters, but with most only existing as portraits in the main menu.

The music does a better job of capturing the theme of the story than the writing. Much like the Ys games, it felt at times like I was playing it more to enjoy the music than anything else, with the story only becoming more nonsensical the further I got into it. Most character development happens off screen, and the stakes are so poorly telegraphed I had no idea what was going on when the end came. At one point the connection between the game and story breaks down completely, making it clear no effort was made to make the parts gel. It’s inelegant, and because of how thin it is, Volume ends up being both blunt and vague.

So the story is disappointing. But if you approach it with this in mind, that it’s primarily about stealth puzzle challenges, then it’s still reasonably fun. Thanks to the music it felt like a nice place to be. With every level taking 2-5 minutes to finish, it was easy to just keep playing, even if the next map probably wouldn’t add anything to the story. It’s not bad, but I am disappointed.

For those of you expecting there to be guns and grenades...not the game for you. Those of you who love stealth with tools to distract and counter guards (no killing) then this is the game for you.

It is a really interesting game to play, where even in the later stages of the 100 core levels you are introduced to new techniques which can be combined with others to make you a master of stealth and distraction. The game is a modern twist on the classic tale of Robin Hood with a heavy influence of the VR training missions from the older Metal Gear Solid games. Visually it is quite astounding to see. Most of the games design is based around the shape of a tittle (diamond shape with sharp edges). The colour scheme throughout the 100 core levels reflect not only the story but also the environment that is being simulated.

Voice acting goes along way in this game. Some people dislike it, others like it. I for one enjoy hearing the dialogue to help draw me into the world created by the visuals, gameplay and ambient sounds. Keep in mind that I have only played the game for about an hour, but have been following its development closely. Consider this a first glance review.

Greatly inspired by Metal Gear Solid and Metal Gear Solid 2: Sons of Liberty, especially the accompanying VR missions for those games, the game takes the best from its influence and simplifies it in a fun, challenging and pick-up-and-play way. Simplification here is not bad, at all, nor does it imply a lack of content or depth in the game. It is from actual appreciation of its inspiration that the game manages to deliver some good stealth puzzle action. I have always wanted an expansion to the MGS’s VR missions, and Volume fulfills that gap.

This isn’t to say that Volume is just a direct replica. It has its own feel, own way of playing and its own experience. But it can’t be overlooked that it serves to revitalize a stealth genre that is honestly not looked into more. First, “Not the Robots”, and now “Volume” are bringing back stealth puzzle games, and I love it.

From my short play of the game, the controls feel responsive and intuitive. I did come across some weird audio glitches where characters say lines out of nowhere, without context, that they have said before. I’m not sure if this is intentional or a glitch that can later be fixed, but it did distract me a few times.

Visuals are great, again, the MGS VR inspiration is very apparent, but the “volumetric” approach to how the maps look is striking, To put it simply, I really like it.

reviewText:
I'll admit that I bought this game solely because I am such a huge fan of Thomas Was Alone. I mean, I don't even like stealth sections in games, let alone entire games about stealth.

However, what I found was that although I don't like stealth games, I love puzzle games, which is what I found this game to be. The gameplay is simply phenomenal, and the stealth puzzles are all extremely intuitive. I found that I could easily solve most puzzles on my first try about halfway through the game because I started getting into the game's rythm of which way guards are most likely to turn and the best way to use items to get guards to look the other way for long enough to get the thing.

When it did turn into a stealth game, I got my ♥♥♥ kicked. I'm looking at you lasers.

The plot was very good, and it's the type of game where you have to piece together a lot of information from the clues the game gives you to get a greater understanding of the world. And I was so very pleased near the beginning to discover that this universe is the same one that Thomas Was Alone takes place in.

I did some trouble with the menu though. Going in for the first time I found the opening menu a bit un-intuitive. It didn't seem to like the Xbox controller I was using, and some of the menus were clearly meant to only be used with a mouse. The first instance that springs to mind is when scrolling through the list of the 100 main-story missions. This takes 5 seconds with a mouse, 5 minutes pressing down on the controller. Also when you unlock character customization, it's impossible to select a color with the controller (Bright Green Ninja Thief of course). But honestly when the worst thing about your game is the menu then that's something to celebrate.

The gameplay is varied and extremely fun with new items to help you sneak around showing up every 15-20 levels and new enemies/obstacles that are immune to those items showing up at about the same rate. The backgrounds and sets are all absolutely gorgeous. The difficulty can spike at times (f'ing lasers) which caused me to breeze through a batch of levels before bashing my head against the wall on one level for as long as I spent on the easy ones combined. And the game itself is incredibly addicting.

I'd highly recommend this game for anyone and everyone. Some mechanical aspects of it could probably use a good spit-shine which may be done in updates, but the core game is still a gem. I'm really looking forward to what Mike Bithell gives us next!

reviewText:
Comparisons with Metal Gear Solid always were inevitable considering the top-down/isometric stealth gameplay and simplistic blocky geometry. Indeed, reading the 'Making Of' e-book, the developer takes some time relating in depth his collating of stealth games like Metal Gear and Hitman for inspiration. There's even a humourous anecdote of a meeting between hin and Kojima-san. The e-book, it turns out, is a must-read for all aspiring game developers.

Volume itself takes the gameplay of games like Metal Gear, Hitman, Splinter Cell et al, and distills it into its purest form. But its when the soundtrack kicks in, with its 3-note motif, more than a passing nod to the Tomb Raider theme, that it hits you: above all else, Volume is not just a stealth game, its a fan-made homage to all those games of the 80's & 90's, Tomb Raider included.

Games whose gameplay preceeded 'realism' and, using Tomb Raider as an example, were just a series of conceptual puzzles strung together in a narrative. Volume then is a genuine harkback to those 'golden-days' of gaming.
So, avoid guards (and their triangular lines-of-sight), collect orbs to create an exit and use some genuinely fun gadgets. Gaming has suddenly become fun again.

reviewText:
This review was written for FREEDOM Community Gaming Collective[freedomcgc.com].
Stealing from the rich and giving to the poor is an old concept all of us are familiar with. Volume provides a futuristic re-telling of the classic Robin Hood story wrapped up in a tightly designed stealth puzzle package. Players take on the role of Rob Locksley on a journey through one hundred self-contained and relatively short levels mostly to steal information and valuables from the head of a huge and powerful corporation that effectively rules over England.

Volume utilizes an isometric camera. However, when hugging a wall, it shifts to a top-down view so you can get a clearer overview. One of the first things you’ll notice about the game is its clean and simple visual aesthetic. As you go through the game, almost each level features a different color palette. Levels usually consist of only two or three main colors, but they are expertly used to create a striking visual style. Not only is the art style visually pleasing, but it directly facilitates clarity of design. It’s extremely important for stealth games to be instantly clear about everything that is going on, so that the player can effectively plan and react in any given moment. Volume achieves this in an almost effortless way, but it is, in fact, the result of intelligent design.

Volume is actually a simulation within a simulation. As the game starts, Rob hacks and reprograms a hostile artificial intelligence that works for Gisborne, the aforementioned head of Gisborne Industries. The artificial intelligence, Alan, then proceeds to allow Rob access to key locations of the corporation. The story tackles some interesting themes such as the dangers of completely unregulated capitalism, internet celebrities, the fear surrounding artificial intelligence and the ethics of dealing with them. Unfortunately, the problem is that the story isn’t particularly well told. There were some inspired lines that grabbed my attention, but for the most part, it’s rather dull. There are optional texts you can find in each level which provide some backstory, but those are boring for the most part as well. It’s a shame that the story falls flat because the themes it covers are genuinely intriguing.

What really makes Volume shine is the design. Levels are pretty much designed as puzzles and it’s up to you to figure out how to finish them without getting yourself killed. Rob cannot kill any of the enemies in the game, he can only hide or otherwise evade them. He has a variety of tools at his disposal to achieve this. The most basic ability, which will actually remain useful throughout the entire game, is getting the attention of guards by whistling in their proximity. For example, hiding behind a wall and whistling will cause the guards to either move from their spot or break their patrolling pattern in order to investigate the noise. You can use that moment and navigate the space they were guarding. Rob can also use the environment and hide in lockers or jump over certain walls. Later on, the game introduces shadows which effectively make Rob completely invisible in certain spots.

However, the most interesting way to deal with guards is using various gadgets that you will find in each level. Some gadgets will enable you to distract guards by creating noise or place a shiny item that grabs their attention for a while. Others will allow you to stun guards for a precious few seconds, trick them by wearing a disguise or even turning invisible in the later levels. There’s a healthy amount of gadgets to use and each level is designed around using a single or several gadgets.

There’s a nice variety of enemies as well. The most basic ones have a standard cone of sight and will just shoot you in the face with their assault rifles. On the other hand, snipers have narrow and long sight range, but they shoot slower. Knights are fearsome and fast melee enemies with a huge line of sight and they’ll hunt you down and hack you up in a heartbeat. Turrets are stationary, but have an exceptionally fast rate of fire. Dogs won’t directly attack you, but they’ll alert nearby guards of your presence. Also, considering they mostly rely on their ability to sniff you out, they can’t be tricked by disguises. All of these elements provide a lot of variety and help to keep the game fresh from start to finish. But the best thing about Volume is how it masterfully pulls off the synergy between these components and creates a coherent whole.

Volume skillfully straddles the line between being challenging and accessible. You will never get stuck on a level without having a clue as to what you’re supposed to be doing. You also won’t feel as if you’re just going through the motions. The difficulty is just right which makes the pacing almost perfect. I also have to single out the sound design and soundtrack both of which fit the game perfectly and help to create a compelling atmosphere. Your completion time of each level will be uploaded online and you’ll be able to see how you stack up against all players and your friends. Apart from the story mode, Volume also features a robust, easy-to-use level editor. Players can upload their levels and download other people’s levels very easily, it’s all just a couple of button presses away. The problem I had with this is that I simply didn’t crave for more. I felt as if I’ve seen everything and simply had no desire to play more levels. It doesn’t really feel like the type of game that could facilitate hours upon hours of gameplay without running out of steam. But for those players who want more, this could be a potentially great way to get more value out of the game.

Volume is a really good stealth puzzle game featuring incredibly balanced design and pacing with a genuinely strong presentation. It just lacks that certain something that would elevate it into truly great territory. Maybe a compelling story or perhaps bolder design would push it into the realm of absolute excellence, I’m not sure. However, the one thing I’m positive about is that Volume is an easy recommendation for anyone looking for a well-designed stealth puzzle game.

7 OUT OF 10 (VERY GOOD)

Addictive and fun indie stealth game with great soundtrack and awesome voiceovers by Andy Serkis. You are playing as a thief in a distant future, and you're stealing gems from rich and corrupt people. Isometric view helps you to plan your steps and react quickly to what is happening.

You have some simple tools that help you on your quest - you can throw sound decoys to distract your enemies or put 'oddities' on walls to keep them occupied and indifferent to sound. You can use the environment to your advantage as well - stick to low walls to avoid being seen, use doors to hide or sound traps to break enemy movement patterns and get out of tricky situations. Be aware that you cannot kill anybody and that it makes the game even more interesting and fun.

Graphics are interesting and intriguing as well, yet simple enough to allow the game to run smooth even on older PC's. Controls are convenient and intuitive - it's fun to play both on keyboard + mouse and gamepad. With 100 levels and level editor, Volume will keep you occupied for hours. It's definitely worth its price so don't hesitate and grab it - you won't regret it!

Enjoyable, rebellious little Puzzle/Stealth game from the makers of Thomas Was Alone, styled similarly to the VR missions in Metal Gear Solid.

---

+ A ton of levels with adequate variety.
+ Superb voice work.
+ A decent story to keep you going.
+ Simple but easy on the eyes graphical style.
+ Has tools to create and share your own levels.

+/- If you're familiar with puzzle games, the difficulty may be a tad easy.
+/- Has leaderboards for Speed Runners (if you care - I don't).

- Doesn't really feel particularly innovative.

---

I'm not normally one for enjoying indie puzzle games unless they particularly stand out from the crowd, and honestly I didn't expect to enjoy this game much when I first started it... but I did actually.

The gameplay progresses nicely, introducing new mechanics and showing an increase in difficulty towards the end with a well paced story to see you through to getting there.

I don't think I would have gone out of my way to play this game were it not for recieving it in a bundle. It doesn't really break any new ground or absolutely blow you away, but if you enjoy the genre and have the time to spend it's a pretty good little game.

reviewText:
Gameplay
Volume is a very good game.
I bought it when it was €3,99 and I didn't regret it, but it worths €17,99.
The controls are easy to remember, and I didn't run in bugs while playing the game ( except when you open a window the sounds start over ).

Sounds
Didn't recognize any sounds that was from another game or from the internet. Sounds were great, HD quality.

Graphics
Now... This is what I can't decide, because I have a crappy PC, but even on Low, and Normal it looked good.
One downside is that when it's too dark, you turn up the Brightness or the Contrass, but then when it's too bright your retina will burn, and you won't see anything from the level.

The Idea
Simple stealth games, similar to Splinter's Cell, in a different way.

AI
The AI is good, but they move too fast. You cant even get away, if they saw you, and if you hide behind the wall, they come there instantly in a second, and I couldn't even get away ( maybe it was just me ).

Overall
I give it a 8/10 because it's a good game, but saw the idea in different games, but in overall Volume is a very interesting, entertaining, fun, and logical game.

I recommend this game, if you like stealth games!
